definitions.definition: to put something in liquid for a time so that it becomes completely wet; to become completely wet in this way
definitions.sensetop: soak something (in something)soak something with somethingsoak (in something)

examples.text: I usually soak the beans overnight.
If you soak the tablecloth before you wash it, the stains should come out.
He soaked the cloth with petrol.
Leave the apricots to soak for 20 minutes.
I'm going to go and soak in the bath.
Soak the clothes in cold water.
A sudden shower of rain soaked the spectators.

definitions.definition: to enter or pass through something

examples.text: Blood had soaked through the bandage.
The rain had soaked through every layer of his clothing.
Water dripped off the table and soaked into the carpet.

definitions.definition: to obtain a lot of money from somebody by making them pay very high taxes or prices

examples.text: He was accused of soaking his clients.

wordOrigin: Old English socian ‘become saturated with a liquid by immersion’; related to sūcan ‘to suck’.
